is often times when we are considering a particular bold bet to make It is

And I realized that I was the odd person out in these VC pitch sessions because

one thing that can go right It's a very very different framework and it's a it's

wrong to look around the corner to have that paranoia But when it comes to making bold

There's a lot of craters on Mars but this particular crater was very interesting because it had a very clear

incredibly challenging And the Curiosity rover had a
uh 20 kilometer accuracy in where it would land compared to where we wanted it to land For
Perseverance because of the challenging terrain the accuracy range had to be within 40 m That's 500 times smaller
radius that the rover has to land in And
the engineers at NASA worked on ways to modulate the rover and to improve the
algorithms to do entry descent and landing with a higher accuracy They invented what's called terrain relative
navigation Terrain relative navigation basically is evaluating the visual
features that are on the ground and then using that to you know steer the rover
in the right direction much like your self-driving cars would do except there's no GPS and the terrain is a
little different um and a few less a lot less features on on Mars but terrain relative navigation was required to pull
this off It's a lot of software that has to be written to pull this off But if
anybody here really wants to be a roboticist at NASA and interviews and find yourself an interview question
where somebody says "Write terrain relative navigation for me." I've got a cheat sheet for you You take pictures as
you're descending You compare it to an orbital map that you have and you go
left or right based on where things are That's essentially what terrain relative navigation
is and this was something that could have really benefited from a massive
compute platform But you know we and and we had
very quantified objectives here You know 40 m as opposed to 20
km And while it's tempting to just say let's just change the compute platform
to be able to land within that 20 uh that 40 m radius it's important to internalize
that the problem to be solved is not the chipset The problem to be solved is can
we pull this off and there's a famous alleged quote from Einstein that does a
better job than this one It's not clear whether he actually said this or not but apparently when asked what he would do
if he had 60 minutes to save the earth by solving a problem he would spend 59
minutes deciding what the problem is and one minute solving it And what he's actually said though is that the
formulation of a problem is more essential than the solution Sometimes it's really important in a
design review to just step out and say what is the problem we're trying to solve it's one of the most profound
questions that principal engineers ask when they see junior engineers arguing over a particular technology choice So
it's really really important to understand what is the problem that we're that we're solving
And the other part of this why we didn't jump to a new platform right away is you
got to derisk your bold risks as well And that doesn't mean that you the choice isn't

And doing this the ingenuity helicopter turned out to be a platform where we could turn
this into a two-way door And two-way door is a concept released by introduced by Jeff Bezos in a shareholder letter
for Amazon in 2015 where there are some decisions that
are nearly impossible or very expensive to
undo The other decisions are a lot easier And as companies get larger often
times we end up spending the same amount of time debating one-way doors as we
debate the two-way doors And this is hard So if you take a mathematical
perspective on this it means that the one-way door decisions are getting the
same amount of time as the two-way door decisions So the one-way door decisions are getting a lot less time than they
should and the two-way door decisions things that are simpler are being bike
shut upon and there's indecisiveness And the job of a senior
leader is to not take one-way door decisions The job of a senior leader in
a company is to convert as many of your one-way door
decisions into two-way door decisions You can take a unique perspective you can reduce the blast radius And reducing
blast radius is a really good way to convert to transform a one-way door
